title: 113_hr5169
content: The "Senior Executive Service Accountability Act" requires biennial justification of positions and extends the probationary period for senior executives to two years. It also modifies pay retention for senior executives removed for underperformance. The "Senior Executive Service Accountability Act" amends Section 3594(c)(1)(B) of title 5, United States Code, regarding basic pay entitlements for career appointees placed under different subsections. The "Senior Executive Service Accountability Act" amends Section 3594(c)(1)(B) of title 5, United States Code, to ensure career appointees placed under different subsections receive basic pay at the rate in effect for their position. SEC. 5 amends Section 4312(b)(1) of title 5, requiring performance requirements to be established not later than 30 calendar days and communicated in writing. SEC. 6 amends adverse action provisions for career appointees in the Senior Executive Service. (a) Suspension for 14 Days or Less for Senior Executive Service Employee.--Paragraph (1) of Section 7501 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to define an employee as an individual in the competitive service who is not on probation or has completed 1 year of continuous employment in a similar position, or a career appointee in the Senior Executive Service who has completed the probationary period. (b) Modification of Cause and Procedure for Suspension and Termination.--Section 7543 of title 5, United States Code is modified. Section 7543 of title 5, United States Code is amended to modify the cause and procedure for suspension and termination. An agency head may extend deadlines for employee responses or written decisions by up to 30 days each, with written documentation required for any extensions granted. The amendment to Section 7543 of title 5, United States Code allows agency heads to extend deadlines for employee responses or decisions by up to 30 days each, with written documentation required. Additionally, the amendment introduces provisions for employees subject to removal, requiring them to repay any pay received during the removal process and forfeit any accrued annual leave if a final order favors the agency. The amendment to Subchapter V of chapter 35 of title 5, United States Code allows for removal of employees for cause that would promote efficiency of service, including misconduct. The House of Representatives passed the amendment on September 16, 2014. Karen L. Haas attested as the Clerk.
